intro: Cupaniopsis phanerophlebia, commonly known as the coastal cupaniopsis, is a small evergreen shrub native to the coastal regions of southern Australia. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves that are typically arranged in opposite pairs. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are clustered in umbels, followed by fleshy, orange-red berries. It thrives in sandy soils and is adapted to withstand salt spray and coastal winds. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in coastal gardens.
